# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Special Instructions

{{instructions}}

Here is the Julia function that solves this problem:

```julia
function wrap_string(s::AbstractString, text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(s, " ")
    result = ""
    line = ""
    for word in words
        if length(line * " " * word) > text_width
            result *= "\n" * line
            line = word
        else
            line *= " " * word
        end
    end
    result *= "\n" * line
    return result
end
```

This function splits the input string into words, then iterates over each word. It checks if adding a new word to the current line would exceed the `text_width`. If it does, it appends the current line to the result and starts a new line with the current word. Otherwise, it adds the current word to the current line. After processing all words, it appends the last line to the result.

Here is an example usage:

```julia
s = "This is a test string for wrapping text."
println(wrap_string(s))
```

In this case, each word in the string will be printed on a new line if adding it would exceed `text_width=10`.
